Educational post on George Soros's Theory of Reflexivity from his 2009 lecture at Central European University, Budapest. Explains three core concepts: fallibility (human understanding is inherently imperfect), reflexivity (circular relationship between thinking and reality), and human uncertainty principle (participants' biased views affect the situation). Contrasts with Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) which claims markets naturally move toward equilibrium. Soros argues market prices always distort underlying fundamentals, and these distortions can affect the fundamentals they reflect. First cardinal principle: Market prices always distort underlying fundamentals. Essential framework for understanding market cycles and 'mentally zooming out' of daily noise. Referenced as key to understanding 2025 April crash as first sign of changing world order.
Theory of Reflexivity core principles with fallibility, feedback loops, and uncertainty

Educational post distinguishing between stock market gurus (furus) and analysts. Furus provide straightforward statements and clear directional predictions appealing to laypeople who want simple answers without thinking. Analysts discuss complex charts and dynamics without making clear predictions, requiring more sophisticated understanding. Furus live off subscription fees and need to appear accurate, often using marketing tactics. Historical context of fraud following technological advances (telephone, TV, internet). Liberal capitalism critique where consumer becomes product with personal data and ignorance exploited. Consumer protection regulations lax in West with GDP as sole goal. Risk/reward still on short delta side while hedging upside and vol decay.

Intraday analysis for May 6 ahead of FOMC Part 2 on liquidity crisis. M2 inflection points coincide with upsticks in inflation expectations indicating market participants view broad liquidity as key driver of prices supporting bulltrap call. ISM Manufacturing Prices Paid Index returned to expansion October 2024 near 55% climbing to 69.8% in April highest since June 2022. ISM Non-Manufacturing Prices Paid Index jumped from 58% in October 2024 to 65.1% in April strongest since January 2023. Readings above 50% signal majority of firms paying more for inputs. Both surveys spent seven straight months above 60% consistent with sustained price pressures. Month-to-month swings of 4-5 points reflect tariff cycles, commodity price moves (steel, lumber), and freight bottlenecks passing through to higher procurement costs. Five of six largest manufacturing industries reported higher raw-material costs in April. In services, only arts and recreation reported lower input costs. Despite Fed tightening, input-cost inflation remains entrenched. Prices Paid above 60% historically maps to PPI increases well above target eventually printing into CPI strongly against rate cuts. Margin squeeze as firms face shrinking margins unless passing costs to consumers in slowing economy increasing stagflation.

Intraday analysis for December 23 (GDP & PCE day). GDP came up higher than expected, highest since Q3 2023. Real GDP (Q3 2025, SAAR): +4.3% (Q2 was +3.8%). PCE price index +2.8% (Q2: +2.1%) and core PCE even higher at +2.9% (Q2: +2.6%). Gross private domestic investment roughly flat (-0.02pp), inventories a drag (-0.22pp). Sizable part of upside GDP from imports falling, mechanically boosting GDP. Cleaner 'underlying demand' read is real final sales to private domestic purchasers at +3.0% (still strong, but meaningfully below 4.3%). Meaningful portion of headline strength came from trade/import dynamics, while underlying domestic-demand proxy 'only' 3.0%. Reduces case for clean, broad-based earnings acceleration, so rates headwind can dominate. Narrative matters: if market concludes GDP 'heat' is backward-looking noise and keeps pricing same Fed path, can be bullish later. Now, it's a headwind for risk assets. Risk remains.

Intraday analysis for October 2 on Gold rally and hedging curve-steepening risk with practical recommendations. Gold rally chiefly supported by central banks and ETF demand. Fed's easing bias and upside risk to breakevens are bullish pillars. Gold is effectively short beta to real yields, so biggest left-tail risk is real-yield backup / curve steepener. Gold is a hedge/insurance against inflation/real-rate factors, not a compounding engine. Size gold exposure by risk budget and factor diversification, not notional, managing overlap with duration/breakeven risk. Recommendations for hedging: TY/US put spreads (short 10y/long-bond futures via puts) sized by DV01 to estimated gold-rates beta; bear-steepener options (2s10s/5s30s payer spreads) to cover potential curve-steepening risk; GLD/XAU puts or collars (e.g., 3-6M 25d put financed with 10-15d call sale) to protect against ETF-inflow stall/reversal. Downside is on the table if ETF inflows stop. Simpler collars or multi-asset inflation sleeve (gold + TIPS + commodities) to diversify bet if not set up for rate hedges.

Intraday analysis for October 22 on Gold selloff and China tariffs. Gold selloff not tied to one headline, looked like positioning/flow event after nine-week uptrend, steepest daily fall since 2020. Gold broke $4,000, $4,100, $4,200 with 1M GLD IV ~30% and IV-RV ~12.5% very rich driven by rate-cut bets, geopolitics, ETF/CB demand, making correction inevitable. Drivers didn't disappear, author remains bullish on Gold until 3100/3200 zone holds. 3700/3800 area possible if 4k weak, good buy-the-dip opportunity for long-term hold. New U.S. tariff actions on China in play this month with separate USTR action targeting Chinas maritime/logistics/shipbuilding ecosystem. Beijing counter-moved with port fees on U.S. ships (waivers favor China-built tonnage) and litigating at WTO. Rare-earths/critical minerals tightness risk if counters escalate. Tariffs are a cost-push. Spring hikes triggered China's WTO case. 100% rate would amplify pass-through unless offset by discounting/FX. Desks price higher front-end equity vol on tariff days. Haven demand (gold, bills) persists even when equities rebound on 'deal talk'. SPX positioning to be analyzed.

Intraday analysis for December 22 (IC day). Refers to the weekly post on GDP release (Dec 22-26). Focuses on daily positioning for intraday trades.
High-frequency trading algorithm disadvantage - retail traders cannot compete with HF algos due to slower condition reading and emotional discipline limitations
Intraday edge opportunity timing - maximum 1-2 opportunities per day, typically during AM session and after 2 PM
0DTE position taking impact - first 20-30 minutes show high intraday volatility as people take 0DTE positions
Market structure observation methodology - wait 30-40 minutes for market to show direction, build structure, retest support/resistance, reveal net drift and influential effects
Daily trading budget management - set daily budget including loss limits and profit limits based on personal capital assessment
Trading side familiarity and conviction - choose long or short side based on familiarity and 'feel', then wait for specific conditions to execute
Patient trade execution discipline - wait for market to provide setup, avoid FOMO, leave desk if no setup appears, not obligated to trade
Trade planning and explanation requirement - must be able to explain trade reasoning to self or spouse, understand decision logic completely
Loss acceptance within limits - worst case is being wrong and taking loss within predetermined limits, prevents insecurity and over-hesitation
Order type selection strategy - use market orders for fast jump-in trades, limit orders for calculated patient trades, no trailing stop-loss
Options delta management and rolling - when trade goes favorable and momentum proves, size up and roll contracts at 80-85 delta back toward 550 delta
Options selection by delta profile - use 60/70 delta ITM contracts for intraday due to theta, 50 delta ATMs for high conviction, 22 delta OTMs for swing trades
Market maker positioning awareness - exit quickly when MM positioning shows short fly pattern due to higher theta bleed risk
Distribution-based position sizing - trade distribution using simulated probability values with modified Heston-Nandi model, size winners and close losers
Dollar cost averaging limits - maximum 3 DCA entries when betting on long volatility, typically only 2 legs

Multi-level analysis framework - use reversion levels for probabilities, positioning-based levels for support/resistance and dynamic shifts, momentum script for direction, educational posts for risk insights

Intraday analysis for August 12 on inflation expectations and perspectives. Weekly post (CPI and OpEx week, August 11-15) referenced. Market trends at centroid of weekly OpEx positioning. Sentiment driven by earnings and Sept cut hopes. Market pricing and what happens in certain scenarios. Risk determination and hedging, not guessing race. CPI and PPI release to reveal government influence on Fed. Disinflation vs tariff-generated pressures causing sticky/climbing inflation. Market expects front-end inflation (1-3 year window) due to tariffs, moderating later. Inflation swaps curve declined since QT in 2022, bottomed when Fed first cut rates. In April/May, despite recessionary/deflationary concerns, market expected higher inflation due to tariffs and stagflationary pressures. Market expects neutral print, sticky uncertainty, waiting for PPI and Jackson Hole, expanding risk window. OpEx will cap downside. If inflationary pressures not significant or hint of cooling, and Sept cut happens, market will take profit. Fed doesn't cut due to no-inflation, but due to policy. This would be a clear sign of policy error.
